keywords: Large woody debris (LWD), EMAP protocol, ecological condition, western wadable streams, measurement, diameter class, length class, bankfull channel.

abstract:
This method is used to assess the amount and distribution of large woody debris (LWD) in western wadable streams as part of an Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP). The assessment of LWD is important for estimating the ecological condition of the stream.

The method involves measuring and recording the diameter and length of large wood pieces (minimum 10 cm in diameter and 1.5 m in length) within two categories: those that are at least partially within the bankfull channel, and those that are not but are still bridging the channel.

This information is gathered through a simplified adaptation of methods described by Robison and Beschta (1990). By determining the diameter class and length class for each piece of LWD and tallying their numbers within each category, we can gain quantitative estimates of the volume and distribution of this important habitat feature.

The necessity of this method lies in its ability to provide valuable data on LWD, which plays a significant role in maintaining the ecological health and productivity of wadable streams. This information is crucial for monitoring changes in stream conditions over time, identifying trends or issues, and making informed decisions regarding stream management and conservation efforts.

description:
The provided text describes a method for measuring Large Woody Debris (LWD) in western wadable streams as part of an Environmental Monitoring and Assessment Program (EMAP). This technique is based on the EMAP physical habitat characterization protocol and follows instructions for quantitatively estimating the number, size, total volume, and distribution of wood within a stream reach. LWD is defined as woody material with a small end diameter of at least 10 cm (4 in.) and a length of at least 1.5 m (5 ft.).

The method begins by determining the diameter class of the large end of each LWD piece. The diameter is measured using standard diameter classes, such as less than 30 cm (12 in.), 30-60 cm (12-24 in.), and so on. This measurement provides important information about the size distribution of LWD within the stream reach.

The next step involves determining the length class for each LWD piece. The length is measured from the small end to the largest point along the length of the piece that is still in contact with the stream bed or bank. Length classes can include categories such as less than 2 m (6.5 ft.), 2-4 m (6.5-13 ft.), and so on.

After determining the diameter and length classes for each LWD piece, they are tallied within segments that are at least partially within the bankfull channel. The bankfull channel is defined as the maximum width and depth a stream can reach during a bankful discharge event. This measurement of LWD provides insight into the amount and distribution of woody debris within the main active channel of the stream.

The final step involves tallying LWD pieces that are not actually within the bankfull channel, but are at least partially spanning (bridging) it. These pieces play an essential role in connecting the banks of the stream and creating habitats for various organisms. By including them in the LWD measurement, a more comprehensive understanding of the physical habitat conditions is obtained.

This method is a simplified adaptation of those described by Robison and Beschta (1990). It offers valuable data to assess the ecological condition of western wadable streams and supports effective management of aquatic ecosystems.
